title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
1 1.0 LIBRARIES —-
library(dplyr) library(vroom) library(ggplot2) library(data.table) # 2.0 ASSIGNING COLUMN TYPES col_types <- list( id = col_character(), patent_id = col_character(), assignee_id = col_character(), mainclass_id = col_character(), type = col_character(), number = col_character(), country = col_character(), organization = col_character(), date = col_date(“%Y-%m-%d”), abstract = col_character(), title = col_character(), kind = col_character(), num_claims = col_double(), filename = col_character(), withdrawn = col_double(), sequence = col_integer() )


2 3.0 IMPORTING FILES INTO TABLES
patent_tbl <- vroom( file = “C:/Users/Preethi Aranala/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/ss23-bdsb-PreethiAranala/content/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/patent.tsv”, delim = “, col_types = col_types[c(”id”, ”date”, ”num_claims”)], na = c(”“,”NA”, “NULL”) )
patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom( file = “C:/Users/Preethi Aranala/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/ss23-bdsb-PreethiAranala/content/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/patent_assignee.tsv”, delim = “, col_types = col_types[c(”patent_id”, ”assignee_id”)], na = c(”“,”NA”, “NULL”) )
assignee_tbl <- vroom( file = “C:/Users/Preethi Aranala/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/ss23-bdsb-PreethiAranala/content/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/assignee.tsv”, delim = “, col_types = col_types[c(”id”, ”type”, ”organization”)], na = c(”“,”NA”, “NULL”) )
uspc_tbl <- vroom( file = “C:/Users/Preethi Aranala/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/ss23-bdsb-PreethiAranala/content/Patent_data_reduced/Patent_data_reduced/uspc.tsv”, delim = “, col_types = col_types[c(”patent_id”, ”mainclass_id”, ”sequence”)], na = c(”“,”NA”, “NULL”) ) # 3.1 Question 1 # 3.1.1 Manipulating the data
patent_assignee_dt <- merge(patent_assignee_tbl, assignee_tbl, by.x = “assignee_id”, by.y = “id”, all.x = T) %>% filter(type == 2) %>% group_by(organization) %>% summarize(quantity = n()) %>% arrange(desc(quantity))


3 3.1.2 Visualizing the data
patent_assignee_dt %>% slice(1:10) %>% ggplot(aes(x=organization, y=quantity)) + geom_label(aes(label = quantity), vjust = -0.2) + geom_col(fill = “#2DC6D6”) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+ labs( title = “Patents by Top US Companies”, x = “Top 10 US Companies”, # Override defaults for x and y y = “Quantity” )


4 3.2.1
patent_dt2 <- patent_tbl %>% left_join(patent_assignee_tbl, by = c(“id” = “patent_id”)) %>% left_join(assignee_tbl, by = c(“assignee_id” = “id”)) %>% filter(type == 2 & date>= “2014-08-01” & date<= “2014-08-31”) %>% group_by(organization) %>% summarise(quantity = n()) %>% ungroup() %>% arrange(desc(quantity))


5 3.2.2 Visualizing the data
patent_dt2 %>% slice(1:10) %>% ggplot(aes(x=organization, y=quantity)) + geom_label(aes(label = quantity), vjust = -0.2) + geom_col(fill = “#2DC6D6”) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+ labs( title = “Most Patents by Top US Companies in August 2014”, x = “Top 10 US Companies”, # Override defaults for x and y y = “Quantity” )


6 3.3.1
patent_dt3 <- patent_assignee_tbl %>% left_join(assignee_tbl, by = c(“assignee_id” = “id”), relationship = “many-to-many”) %>% left_join(uspc_tbl, by = c(“patent_id” = “patent_id”), relationship = “many-to-many”)
top_10_companies <- patent_dt3 %>% group_by(organization) %>% summarise(num_patents = n()) %>% top_n(10, num_patents)
top_5_USPTO <- patent_dt3 %>% filter(organization %in% top_10_companies$organization) %>% group_by(mainclass_id) %>% summarise(num_patents_per_mainclass = n()) %>% na.omit() %>% top_n(5,num_patents_per_mainclass)
top_5_USPTO %>% ggplot(aes(x=mainclass_id, y=num_patents_per_mainclass)) + geom_label(aes(label = num_patents_per_mainclass), vjust = -0.2) + geom_col(fill = “#2DC6D6”) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+ labs( title = “Top 5 USPTO Classes by Top 10 Companies”, x = “Main Class ID”, # Override defaults for x and y y = “Quantity” )

title: Data Visualization
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Tidyverse
text:
1 SALES ANALYSIS —-

2 1.0 Loading necessary libraries —-

library(tidyverse)
library(readxl)


3 2.0 Importing Files —-

bikes_tbl <- read_excel("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/bikes.xlsx")

bikeshops_tbl <- read_excel("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/bikeshops.xlsx")

orderlines_tbl <- read_excel("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/01_raw_data/orderlines.xlsx")


4 3.0 Examining Data —-

bikes_tbl %>% glimpse()
bikeshops_tbl %>% glimpse()
orderlines_tbl %>% glimpse()


5 4.0 Joining Data —-

bike_orderlines_joined_tbl <- orderlines_tbl %>%
        left_join(bikes_tbl, by = c("product.id" = "bike.id")) %>%
        left_join(bikeshops_tbl, by = c("customer.id" = "bikeshop.id"))

bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>% glimpse()


6 5.0 Wrangling Data —-

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>%
  separate(col    = location,
           into   = c("city", "state"),
           sep    = ",") %>%
  mutate(total.price = price * quantity) %>%
  select(-...1, -gender) %>%
  select(-ends_with(".id")) %>%
  bind_cols(bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>% select(order.id)) %>% 
  select(order.id, contains("order"), contains("model"), contains("location"),
         price, quantity, total.price,
         everything()) %>%
  rename(bikeshop = name) %>%
  set_names(names(.) %>% str_replace_all("\\.", "_"))


7 6.0 Business Insights —-

8 6.1 Sales by Location —-

9 Step 1 - Manipulate

sales_by_loc_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
group_by(state) %>% 
summarize(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
mutate(revenue = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))

sales_by_loc_tbl


10 Step 2 - Visualize

sales_by_loc_tbl %>%
ggplot(aes(x = state, y = sales)) +
geom_col(fill = "#2DC6D6") + 
geom_label(aes(label = revenue)) + 
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))+                 labs(
    title    = "Revenue by State",
    x = "", # Override defaults for x and y
    y = "Revenue"
  )


11 6.2 Sales by State and Year —-

library(lubridate)


12 Step 1 - Manipulate

sales_by_year_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
select(state, order_date, total_price) %>%
mutate(year = year(order_date)) %>%
group_by(state, year) %>% 
summarize(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))
sales_by_year_tbl


13 Step 2 - Visualize

sales_by_year_tbl %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = state)) +
  geom_col() + # Run up to here to get a stacked bar plot
  facet_wrap(~ state) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by Year and State",
    fill = "States" 
  )


14 7.0 Writing Files —-

library(writexl)


15 7.1 Excel —-

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>% 
write_xlsx("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/02_wrangled_data/bike_orderlines.xlsx")


16 7.2 CSV —-

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>% 
write_csv("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/02_wrangled_data/bike_orderlines.csv")


17 7.3 RDS —-

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>% 
write_rds("00_raw_data/01_bike_sales/02_wrangled_data/bike_orderlines.rds")

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website everytime before you want to upload changes

title: Links

Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .
